Question.heading: EP-X can be filed in Danish.

Explanation: A European patent application can be filed in any language, including Danish, as per Article 14(2) EPC.

Question.heading: EP-X can be filed in Korean.

Explanation: A European patent application can be filed in any language, including Korean, as per Article 14(2) EPC.

Question.heading: EP-X can be filed in Japanese.

Explanation: A European patent application can be filed in any language, including Japanese, as per Article 14(2) EPC.

Question.heading: If EP-X is not filed in one of the official languages of the EPO, then a translation into an official language of the EPO must be filed within a time limit of one month.

Explanation: If a European patent application is not filed in one of the official languages, a translation must be filed within two months of filing the application, not one month.

Question.heading: Mr X can validly claim priority if he files the European patent application on 10 April 2012.

Explanation: Mr X can claim priority if he files the European patent application within 12 months from the priority date, which is extended to 10 April 2012 due to Easter holidays.
Legal basis: Article 87(1) EPC, Rule 131(4) EPC, Rule 134(1) EPC

Question.heading: The priority declaration must be made at the latest on 10 August 2012.

Explanation: The priority declaration must be made within sixteen months from the priority date claimed, i.e., latest on 6 August 2012.

Question.heading: If Mr X had filed a German utility model application instead of a German patent application, it would have been possible to claim priority from the German utility model application.

Explanation: A utility model application also gives rise to a right of priority, as per Article 87(1) EPC.

Question.heading: Mr X can claim priority from the German patent application even if the German patent application is abandoned before filing of the European patent application.

Explanation: The outcome of the priority application (such as a subsequent withdrawal) is irrelevant for claiming priority, as per Article 87(3) EPC.

Question.heading: One of the elements that the EPO as receiving Office has to receive today in order to accord today's date as the filing date for the PCT application is... the description.

Explanation: A description is required for obtaining an international filing date, as per Article 11(iii)(d) PCT.

Question.heading: One of the elements that the EPO as receiving Office has to receive today in order to accord today's date as the filing date for the PCT application is... the abstract.

Explanation: The abstract is not required for obtaining an international filing date.

Question.heading: One of the elements that the EPO as receiving Office has to receive today in order to accord today's date as the filing date for the PCT application is... one or more claims.

Explanation: One or more claims are required for obtaining an international filing date, as per Article 11(iii)(e) PCT.

Question.heading: One of the elements that the EPO as receiving Office has to receive today in order to accord today's date as the filing date for the PCT application is... the title of the invention.

Explanation: The title of the invention is not required for obtaining an international filing date.

Question.heading: In the international PCT phase, the applicant can file a protest with the EPO and request that a full search is made. The protest is free of charge, but it has to be supported by arguments.

Explanation: The protest is not free of charge; a prescribed protest fee must be paid, as per Rule 158(3) EPC.

Question.heading: The applicant can timely pay one additional fee for the third invention to be searched in the international PCT phase. In the European phase, the applicant can limit the application to the third invention.

Explanation: The applicant can pay an additional fee for the third invention to be searched and can limit the application to that invention in the European phase, as per Rule 164(2) EPC.

Question.heading: The applicant can ignore the invitation. In the European phase, the applicant can file a divisional application directed to the third invention.

Explanation: The applicant can file a divisional application directed to the third invention in the European phase, as per Article 76(1) EPC.

Question.heading: The applicant can ignore the invitation. In the European phase, the applicant will again receive an invitation to pay additional search fees.

Explanation: The applicant will not receive another invitation to pay additional search fees in the European phase if the international search report was drawn up by the EPO, as per Article 153(7) EPC.

Question.heading: The subject-matter of claim 2 of EP2 lacks inventive step.

Explanation: The subject-matter of claim 2 of EP2 is inventive as it was not obvious to the skilled person until feature B became part of the prior art in December 2011.

Question.heading: If EP2 had not claimed priority from EP1, the patentability of claim 1 of EP2 would not change.

Explanation: If EP2 had not claimed priority from EP1, EP1 would have been prior art under Article 54(3) EPC against EP2, and the content of EP1 would have rendered claim 1 of EP2 not novel.

Question.heading: A valid novelty objection can be made using EP1 against claim 1 of EP2.

Explanation: As EP2 claims priority from EP1, the effective date for feature B is 1 June 2010, and no valid novelty objection can be made using EP1 against claim 1 of EP2.

Question.heading: The subject-matter of claim 2 of EP2 is novel.

Explanation: The subject-matter of claim 2 is novel as it is not disclosed in the prior art: neither US1 nor EP1 disclose the combination of features B and A.

Question.heading: If in EP-2 priority is claimed only from EP-1, the effective date for claim 1 of EP-2 is 12 January 2012.

Explanation: If priority is claimed only from EP-1, the effective date for claim 1 of EP-2 is the filing date of EP-1, which is 12 January 2012.

Question.heading: If in EP-2 priority is claimed only from EP-1, the effective date for claim 2 of EP-2 is 6 September 2012.

Explanation: If priority is claimed only from EP-1, the effective date for claim 2 of EP-2 is the filing date of EP-2, which is 20 December 2012, not 6 September 2012.

Question.heading: If in EP-2 priority is claimed only from US-1, the effective date for claim 1 of EP-2 is 12 January 2012.

Explanation: If priority is claimed only from US-1, the effective date for claim 1 of EP-2 is the filing date of EP-2, which is 20 December 2012, not 12 January 2012.

Question.heading: If in EP-2 priority is claimed only from US-1, the effective date for claim 2 of EP-2 is 20 December 2012.

Explanation: If priority is claimed only from US-1, the effective date for claim 2 of EP-2 is the filing date of US-1, which is 6 September 2012, not 20 December 2012.

Question.heading: The renewal fee for the third year for EP-Z is due on 30 April 2013.

Explanation: The renewal fee for the third year is due on the last day of the month containing the anniversary of the date of filing, which is 30 April 2013.

Question.heading: If the applicant pays the renewal fee for EP-Z with the required additional fee on 9 October 2013, the renewal fee is deemed to be validly paid.

Explanation: The renewal fee with an additional fee may still be paid within six months of the due date, which is 30 April 2013. Therefore, payment on 9 October 2013 is valid.

Question.heading: If the applicant fails to observe the time limit for paying a renewal fee for EP-Z, he may request further processing.

Explanation: Further processing for paying a renewal fee is excluded by the provisions of Article 121(4) EPC and Rule 135(2) EPC.

Question.heading: The renewal fee for the third year for EP-Z could have been validly paid on filing.

Explanation: Renewal fees may not be validly paid more than three months before they fall due, Rule 51(1) EPC, second sentence.

Question.heading: Regarding EP-A, the period for paying the additional fee is two months.

Explanation: The period for paying the additional search fee for EP-A is two months, as per Rule 64(1) EPC.

Question.heading: Regarding EP-A, the additional fee must be paid at the latest by 21 April 2013.

Explanation: The additional fee must be paid at the latest by 22 April 2013, as the period is extended due to the 10-day rule and public holidays.
Legal basis: Rule 64(1) EPC, Rule 126(2) EPC, Rule 131(4) EPC, Rule 134(1) EPC

Question.heading: Regarding PCT-B, the period for paying the additional fee is two months.

Explanation: The period for paying the additional fee for PCT-B is one month, as per Rule 40.1(ii) PCT.

Question.heading: Regarding PCT-B, the additional fee must be paid at the latest by 11 March 2013.

Explanation: The additional fee must be paid at the latest by 11 March 2013, as the period is one month from the date of the communication.

Question.heading: The priority period expires on 1 March 2013.

Explanation: The priority period expires on 28 February 2013, as it is 12 months from the filing date of EP-I (29 February 2012).

Question.heading: The priority declaration must be made at the latest by 1 July 2013.

Explanation: The priority declaration must be made at the latest by 1 July 2013, as it is 16 months from the filing date of EP-I (29 February 2012), extended due to public holidays.
Legal basis: Rule 52(2) EPC, Rule 131(4) EPC, Rule 134(1) EPC

Question.heading: In order to validly claim priority, EP-II must be in respect of the same invention as EP-I.

Explanation: To validly claim priority, EP-II must be in respect of the same invention as EP-I, as per Article 87(1) EPC.

Question.heading: Company X can validly claim priority from EP-I only if it was the applicant of EP-I at the date of filing.

Explanation: Company X can validly claim priority from EP-I even if it was not the applicant of EP-I at the date of filing, as long as it is the successor in title or has been validly transferred the right to claim priority.

Question.heading: EP-D must be filed with the European Patent Office in Berlin, Munich or The Hague.

Explanation: EP-D, as a divisional application, must be filed with the European Patent Office in Berlin, Munich, or The Hague, as per Rule 36(2) EPC.

Question.heading: Renewal fees in respect of EP-P already due today shall also be paid for EP-D.

Explanation: Renewal fees already due for EP-P must also be paid for EP-D, as per Rule 51(3) EPC.

Question.heading: You must first file an appeal against the decision to refuse EP-P before you can validly file EP-D.

Explanation: It is not necessary to file an appeal against the decision to refuse EP-P before filing EP-D, as the application is still pending during the period for filing a notice of appeal.

Question.heading: The language of the proceedings of EP-P and EP-D must be the same.

Explanation: The language of the proceedings of EP-P and EP-D must be the same, as per Rule 36(2) EPC.

Question.heading: In this case, the inventor does not need to be represented by a professional representative before the EPO.
In this case, in order to be validly represented by Mr. A, a signed authorisation must be filed with the EPO.

Legal basis: Article 1(1) and (2) of the Decision of the President of the EPO dated 12 July 2007

Question.heading: If the inventor, after validly appointing Mr. A, wants to appoint a different professional representative before the EPO, Mr. B, from another association, then Mr. B need not provide a signed authorisation, if Mr. A informs the EPO of the change of representative.

Legal basis: Article 1(1) and (2) of the Decision of the President of the EPO dated 12 July 2007

Question.heading: For a change of attorney to be validly registered by the EPO, an administrative fee has to be paid.
The communication is deemed to be delivered on Monday, 26 January 2015, because 25 January 2015 falls on a Sunday.
Without resorting to a legal remedy, the reply to the communication must be filed with the EPO at the latest on 26 May 2015.
Further processing for replying to said communication can be validly requested at the latest on Monday, 27 July 2015.
An extension of the time limit for the reply can be validly requested on 20 May 2015.
The additional search fee can be validly paid on 26 February 2015.
Today, 23 February 2015, you can file an international application PCT-B validly claiming priority from PCT-A, wherein the claims of PCT-B are directed to the second invention.

Legal basis: Article 8(2)(a) PCT and Article 4 C (1) of the Stockholm Act of the Paris Convention

Question.heading: A valid option would be to request a supplementary international search for the second invention of PCT-A to be carried out by the EPO.
According to the provisions of the PCT, the additional search fee is paid directly to the International Searching Authority.
The notice of opposition must be filed at the latest on 18 March 2015.
Mr. Kurz is entitled to a reduction of the opposition fee, if he first files the opposition in Czech and then timely files a translation in English.

Legal basis: Rule 6 EPC as entered into force on 1 April 2014

Question.heading: Mr. Kurz need not file a translation of EP-Y.
If Mr. Kurz wants to use the Slovak language during oral proceedings, it is sufficient to notify the EPO one month before the oral proceedings.
In the present case, the latest date for entering the European phase without resorting to further processing was 2 February 2015.
If PCT-M enters the European phase on 27 March 2015, at least one further processing fee must be paid.
In view of the fact that the EPO considers that the subject-matter of several claims of PCT-M is not novel, it is mandatory to file amended claims on which the examination at the EPO is to be based.
One requirement for validly entering the European phase with PCT-M on 27 February 2015, is that a renewal fee must be paid.

Since third party observations can only be filed concerning issues arising under Articles 52 to 57 EPC, the opposition division will not consider the reasoning concerning lack of sufficiency of disclosure.
The submissions of the third party will be forwarded by the EPO to the patent proprietor.
The submissions of the third party will be accessible to the public through file inspection.
The opposition division is allowed to introduce into the proceedings lack of novelty with respect to claim 1 as a fresh ground for opposition.
As soon as the applicant files the translation of the claims and pays the fee for grant and publication, resumption of the examination proceedings is no longer possible.
If the applicant requests a reasoned amendment to claim 15 today, the applicant must at the same time file the translation of the so amended set of claims and pay the fee for grant and publication.
If the applicant adds two dependent claims to the set of claims today, the examining division will not examine these two claims, unless claims fees are also paid.
Third party observations on EP-D filed with the EPO today are no longer considered by the examining division, since they are late filed.
The communication is deemed to be delivered on 1 January 2016.
If the communication sets a period of two months, the applicant's reply must be filed at the latest on 1 March 2016.
If the communication sets a period of four months, the applicant's reply must be filed at the latest on 2 May 2016.

Legal basis: Rule 126(2) EPC, Rule 131(4) EPC, Rule 134(1) EPC

Question.heading: If the communication sets a period of four months and the applicant does not reply, he can validly request further processing on 4 July 2016.
The designation of the inventor may be rectified even after the grant of EP-F.
The applicant need not provide evidence that an error was made.
If the request is filed by the applicant, the consent of Philippe is required to rectify the designation of the inventor.
If the request is filed by Béatrice, the consent of the applicant is required to rectify the designation of the inventor.
Greta can validly appoint Hassan to represent her before the EPO as the International Searching Authority for PCT-G.
As a general rule, a power of attorney need not be submitted with the EPO in order to appoint a representative to act before the EPO as the International Searching Authority.

According to the provisions of the PCT, it is mandatory that the Demand for International Preliminary Examination is signed by the applicant, even in the case where a representative has been validly appointed.
According to the provisions of the PCT, a representative can only validly withdraw an international application if the representative has filed a power of attorney.

Legal basis: Rule 90bis.5 PCT, Rule 90.4(a) PCT, Rule 90.5(a) PCT

Question.heading: Andrew can seek a stay of proceedings if he provides evidence that he has instituted proceedings against Francesca seeking a decision that Andrew is entitled to the grant of the European patent based on EP-F.

Explanation: Andrew can seek a stay of proceedings if he proves that he has instituted proceedings against Francesca seeking a decision that he is entitled to the grant of the European patent based on EP-F.

Question.heading: Francesca can withdraw EP-F at any time from the date on which Andrew provides evidence to the EPO that he has instituted proceedings against Francesca seeking a decision that Andrew is entitled to the grant of the European patent based on EP-F.

Explanation: From the date Andrew provides evidence, neither the European patent application nor the designation of any Contracting State may be withdrawn until the proceedings for grant are resumed.

Question.heading: No renewal fee has to be paid during a stay of proceedings.

Explanation: Renewal fees must be paid even during a stay of proceedings.

Question.heading: Andrew can validly request that EP-F be refused no later than three months after the decision recognising his entitlement to EP-F has become final.

Explanation: Andrew has three months after the decision recognising his entitlement has become final to request that the European patent application filed by Francesca is refused.

Question.heading: If the opposition division considers that the subject-matter of claim 1 lacks novelty over D1, the opposition division may revoke EP-1 for lack of novelty of the subject-matter of claim 1.

Explanation: Novelty as a new ground may be considered in view of the same document used for deciding upon the ground of lack of inventive step.

Question.heading: If the opposition division considers that the subject-matter of claim 2 lacks inventive step over D2 in combination with D3, the opposition division may revoke EP-1 for lack of inventive step of the subject-matter of claim 2 over D2 in combination with D3.

Explanation: The opposition division may not examine the subject-matter of a claim not covered by the extent of the opposition.

Question.heading: If the opposition division considers that the subject-matter of claim 1 is not sufficiently disclosed, the opposition division may revoke EP-1 because the subject-matter of claim 1 is not disclosed in a manner sufficiently clear and complete for it to be carried out by a person skilled in the art.

Explanation: The opposition division may raise a ground for opposition within the extent of the opposition.

Question.heading: After the opposition division has considered Theresa’s third-party observations, the opposition division may revoke EP-1 based on lack of novelty of the subject-matter of claim 2.

Explanation: The opposition division is limited to examining the subject-matter of claim 1, and third parties are not party to the opposition proceedings.

Question.heading: A board of appeal may decide in a three-member composition without a legally qualified member.

Explanation: The board of appeal requires the presence of at least one legally qualified member.

Question.heading: A board of appeal may exercise any power within the competence of the department which was responsible for the decision appealed.

Explanation: The board of appeal may either exercise any power within the competence of the department which was responsible for the decision appealed or remit the case to that department for further prosecution.

Question.heading: A board of appeal may remit a case to the department which was responsible for the decision appealed for further prosecution.

Explanation: The board of appeal may remit the case to the department which was responsible for the decision appealed for further prosecution.

Question.heading: A board of appeal may base its decision on a fresh ground for opposition only submitted during the appeal proceedings without the consent of the patentee.

Explanation: The board of appeal cannot base its decision on a fresh ground for opposition during appeal proceedings without the consent of the patentee.

Question.heading: It is possible to validly transfer EP-A from Company A to Company B only for the designated contracting states FR and DE.

Explanation: A European patent application can be transferred for one or more designated Contracting States.

Question.heading: The transfer of EP-A may be recorded in the European Patent Register at the request of Company B, upon production of documents providing evidence of such transfer and payment of an administration fee.

Explanation: The transfer may be recorded in the European Patent Register upon request, production of evidence, and payment of an administration fee.
Legal basis: Rule 143(1)(w) EPC, Rule 22(2) EPC, Rule 22(1) EPC

Question.heading: The transfer of a European patent application becomes effective vis-à-vis the EPO only when it is published in the European Patent Register.

Explanation: The transfer is effective vis-à-vis the EPO as soon as the documents according to Rule 22(1) EPC have been produced.

Question.heading: The transfer of a European patent may be recorded in the European Patent Register during the opposition period.

Explanation: A European patent can validly be transferred and the transfer can be recorded in the European Patent Register even during the opposition period or opposition proceedings.
Legal basis: Rule 85 EPC in conjunction with Rule 22 EPC

Question.heading: Roberto and Mario are entitled to a reduction of the filing fee.

Explanation: Roberto and Mario do not have their place of residence or place of business within a contracting state and are not nationals of a contracting state being resident abroad.

Question.heading: EP1 will be accorded by the EPO a filing date, only if the content of EP1 does not extend beyond the content of P1 as originally filed.

Explanation: EP1 can contain additional subject-matter which is not included in P1, but the right to priority will only cover the subject-matter of EP1 which is included in P1.
Legal basis: Article 80 EPC, Rule 40 EPC, Article 88(3) EPC

Question.heading: If the French translation had not been filed in due time, EP1 would be deemed not to have been filed.

Explanation: The legal consequence is that EP1 is considered to be withdrawn, not that it is deemed not to have been filed.

Question.heading: If EP1 is assigned to a British company, the language of the proceedings may be changed to English after registration of the transfer.

Explanation: The language of the proceedings cannot be changed during the proceedings concerning an application.

Question.heading: The renewal fee for EP-A in respect of the third year could have been validly paid on 03 May 2019.

Explanation: The renewal fee in respect of the third year may be validly paid up to 6 months before it falls due (30 September 2019).
Legal basis: Rule 51(1) EPC; Guidelines A-X 5.2.4, OJ EPO 2018 A2

Question.heading: The renewal fee for EP-A in respect of the fourth year was due on 07 September 2020.

Explanation: The renewal fee for the fourth year is due on the last day of the month containing the third anniversary of filing (i.e. 30 September 2020).

Question.heading: The renewal fee for EP-A in respect of the fifth year shall be paid to the EPO.

Explanation: The obligation to pay renewal fees (to the EPO) shall terminate with the payment of the renewal fee due in respect of the year in which the mention of the grant of the European Patent is published in the European Patent Bulletin.
Legal basis: Article 86(2) EPC; Article 141(1) EPC; GL 2018 A-X, 5.1.2

Question.heading: All renewal fees due in respect of EP-A-DIV can be validly paid without an additional fee on 07 June 2021.

Explanation: All renewal fees already due in respect of the earlier application at the date on which the divisional application is filed are due on filing. These fees and any renewal fee due within 4 months of filing the divisional may be paid within the same 4 months without an additional fee.

Question.heading: PCT-1 can validly claim priority from FR-1.

Explanation: Priority can be claimed in an international application filed within 12 months from the priority date. The applicant and the subject matter is the same.
Legal basis: Article 8(2)a) and Rule 4 PCT, Article 4C(1) Paris Convention

Question.heading: Anna can validly file the priority declaration in May 2021.

Explanation: The priority declaration can be added within a time limit of 16 months from the priority date.

Question.heading: PCT-1 cannot validly claim priority from FR-1, if FR-1 has been abandoned before the filing of PCT-1.

Explanation: Once the priority application has a filing date, the fate of the priority application is not relevant for the priority claim.
Legal basis: Article 8.2(a) PCT and Article 4A(3) Paris Convention

Question.heading: The filing fee for PCT-1 shall be paid directly to the International Bureau.

Explanation: The filing fee shall be paid within one month from the date of receipt of PCT-1 to the receiving Office.

Question.heading: EP-P-DIV1 was not validly filed as a divisional application of EP-P, because EP-P-DIV1 was filed before the publication of EP-P.

Explanation: The earlier patent application must be pending. There is no requirement that the earlier patent application is published.

Question.heading: If EP-P was filed in Portuguese and translated into English, EP-P-DIV1 must be filed in English.

Explanation: EP-DIV1 may be filed in the language on which the earlier application was filed (Portuguese) or translated (English).

Question.heading: For EP-P-DIV2 an additional fee as part of the filing fee for a divisional application of a second generation had to be paid.

Explanation: EP-DIV2, as it derives from EP-P, is not a second generation divisional application. Thus, an additional fee has not to be paid.

Question.heading: EP-P will be regarded as prior art under Art. 54(2) EPC against EP-P-DIV2.

Explanation: The filing date of EP-DIV2 remains 16 December 2018 and EP-P is not prior art under Art. 54(2) EPC.
Legal basis: Article 76(1) EPC; G1/05 and G1/06, GL C-IX, 1.4

Question.heading: If PCT-A contains 20 claims, claims fees shall be paid for five claims within one month of the date of filing.

Explanation: There is no claims fee for PCT applications.

Question.heading: The period for entering the European phase will expire on 02 October 2023.

Explanation: The time limit is 31-months from the priority date, i.e. 27.9.2022.

Question.heading: The publication date of PCT-A can be postponed, if the claim to priority is validly withdrawn before completion of the technical preparations for international publication.

Explanation: The postponement of the international publication by withdrawing its claim for priority is allowed.

Question.heading: For PCT-A to be considered as comprised in the state of the art under Article 54(3) EPC, it is sufficient that PCT-A is published in English.

Explanation: The requirements of Article 153(5) together with Rule 165 EPC have to be met so that also the filing fee under Rule 159(1)(c) EPC has to be paid.

Question.heading: If the notice of opposition has not been signed by the opponent or by his representative before expiry of the opposition period, the opposition division shall reject the opposition as inadmissible.

Explanation: If the notice of opposition has not been signed within the opposition period, the EPO will invite the opponent to correct this deficiency and if the opponent does not correct this deficiency within the specified time limit, the opposition is deemed not to have been filed.
Legal basis: Rule 76(3) EPC in conjunction with Rule 50(3) EPC; Rule 77(2) EPC in conjunction with Rule 50(3) EPC, Guidelines D-III, 3.4 and D-IV, 1.2.1 (ii) and D-IV, 1.4.1

Question.heading: Competitor B shall file a statement setting out for the first time the grounds of opposition within two months from the date of filing the notice of opposition.

Explanation: The notice of opposition shall contain the grounds on which the opposition is based and has to be filed within 9 months of the mention of the publication of the mention of the grant of the EP patent.

Question.heading: Provided that the opposition proceedings are still pending, competitor Z can file an admissible notice of intervention within three months of the date on which the proceedings for a ruling that competitor Z is not infringing patent EP-G are instituted.

Explanation: Competitor Z can file an admissible notice of intervention within three months of the date on which the proceedings for a ruling that competitor Z is not infringing patent EP-G are instituted.
Legal basis: Article 105(1)(b) EPC in conjunction with Rule 89(1) EPC

Question.heading: If W files third party observations before expiry of the nine-month opposition period, W will be summoned to any oral proceedings taking place before the opposition division.

Explanation: A third party filing observations does not become party to the opposition proceedings and, in consequence, W will not be summoned to any oral proceedings.
Legal basis: Article 115 EPC last sentence; Rule 115(1) EPC

Question.heading: On the basis of the information given above, you can file today a European patent application EP-P, which will be accorded 25 February 2019 as the date of filing, in Pietro’s name at the EPO.

Explanation: Since you can comply today with the requirements of Rule 40(1)(a), (b) and (c) EPC, the date of filing will be 25 February 2019.

Question.heading: On the basis of the information given above, you can be sure that EP-P can validly claim priority from IT-P.

Explanation: For validly claiming the priority, Gianna must have transferred the priority right to Pietro before the filing date of EP-P.

Question.heading: You can validly file EP-P in Italian.

Explanation: A European patent application may be filed in any language.

Question.heading: Pietro as a natural person is not entitled to a reduction of the filing fee.

Explanation: Being a national of the Contracting State Italy and being a natural person, Pietro is entitled to a reduction of the filing fees.

Question.heading: You will be allowed to make oral submissions at the oral proceedings.

Explanation: The representative is allowed to make oral submissions.
Legal basis: Article 133(2) EPC; Guidelines E-III, 8.5 and G4/95

Question.heading: As a general rule, Jane will be allowed to make oral submissions at the oral proceedings.

Explanation: Submissions by a person who is not qualified under Article 133 and 134 EPC cannot be made as of right.

Question.heading: As a general rule, Pedro will be allowed to make oral submissions at the oral proceedings.

Explanation: Submissions by a person who is not qualified under Article 133 and 134 EPC cannot be made as of right.

Question.heading: If the parties and the opposition division agree, Sarah will be allowed to make oral submissions in Portuguese at the oral proceedings.

Explanation: Sarah would be allowed to make submissions in Portuguese if the parties and the European patent office agree to use this language.

Question.heading: The first communication in respect of EP-Z that can be expected from the examining division is a communication under Rule 71(3) EPC.

Explanation: Since a favourable written opinion was established, a communication under Rule 71(3) EPC can be expected as the first communication of the examining division.

Question.heading: If you receive a communication under Rule 71(3) EPC for EP-Z in October 2019 and if you fulfil all the requirements of Rule 71(5) EPC on 31 January 2020, no fees other than the grant and publishing fee are due.

Explanation: The renewal fee for the third year is due on 31 January 2020, and the decision to grant is not issued until the renewal fee has been paid.

Question.heading: It is possible to cancel the designation of Alina as an inventor of EP-Z without Alina's consent.

Explanation: The consent of the wrongly designated person (Alina) is required.

Question.heading: PCT-Z will be deemed to be withdrawn, once a patent is granted on the basis of EP-Z.

Explanation: The PCT does not provide for an international application (PCT-Z) to be deemed to be withdrawn, once a patent is granted on the basis of the priority application (EP-Z).

Question.heading: If Didier files the application in Dutch, he must file a translation into one of the EPO's official languages within two months of filing the application.

Explanation: A translation of the description must be filed in one of the official languages within the period of two months.
Legal basis: Article 14(2) EPC; Rule 6(1) EPC; Guidelines A-VII, 1.1

Question.heading: Didier can pay the search fee in May 2019 provided he requests further processing.

Explanation: If the search fee is not paid within one month of the filing of the European patent application, the application will be deemed to be withdrawn. However, the time limit under Rule 38(1) EPC is not ruled out for further processing.
Legal basis: Rule 38(1) EPC; Article 121(1) and (4) EPC; Rule 135(2) EPC

Question.heading: If Didier does not submit any claims either on filing or within the time limit set by the EPO in a communication inviting him to correct this deficiency, Didier can validly request further processing and file the claims.

Explanation: If Didier does not file claims in accordance with Rule 57(c) and Rule 58 EPC, then Didier cannot validly request further processing, since it is ruled out under Rule 135(2) EPC.
Legal basis: Rule 57(c) EPC; Rule 58 EPC; Rule 135(2) EPC; Guidelines A-III, 15

Question.heading: To validly file a European patent application, Didier can file a reference to a previously filed application, wherein the reference contains (i) the filing date of the previous application, (ii) the file number of the previous application, (iii) the office where the previous application was filed and (iv) an indication that this reference replaces the description and any drawings.

Explanation: To validly file a European patent application, Didier can file a reference to a previously filed application, wherein the reference contains the required information.

Question.heading: During opposition proceedings, an amendment to a European patent introducing subject-matter which was present only in the priority document but not in the European patent application as filed is allowable under Article 123(2) EPC.

Explanation: Under Article 123(2) EPC, it is not allowable to add matter to a European patent present only in the priority document.

Question.heading: Intermediate generalisations are never allowable under Article 123(2) EPC.

Explanation: Intermediate generalisations may be allowable under specific circumstances.

Question.heading: An amendment introducing subject-matter which was present only in the abstract of the application is allowable under Article 123(2) EPC.

Explanation: The abstract may not be taken into account for any purpose other than for technical information.

Question.heading: An amendment introducing subject-matter which was present only in the claims filed in reply to a communication under Rule 58 EPC in conjunction with Rule 57(c) EPC is allowable under Article 123(2) EPC.

Explanation: Subject-matter present only in claims filed after the date of filing goes beyond the subject-matter of the application as filed.

Question.heading: If Daniela ignores the invitation, EP-D will be deemed to be withdrawn.

Explanation: If Daniela ignores the invitation, any reference to the drawings will be deemed to be deleted, but the application is not deemed to be withdrawn.

Question.heading: If Daniela files the missing drawings on 3 May 2018, EP-D will receive 3 May 2018 as its date of filing.

Explanation: If the missing drawings are filed within two months of the notification, the application shall be re-dated to the date on which the missing drawings were filed.

Question.heading: Daniela may validly file the missing drawings for EP-D on 6 June 2018, provided she pays the fee for further processing.

Explanation: Further processing is ruled out in respect of the period under Rule 56(2) EPC.

Question.heading: If an applicant is not invited by the EPO to file missing parts of the description or missing drawings, he may validly file them within two months of the date of filing.

Explanation: An applicant may file missing parts of the description or missing drawings of his own motion within two months of the date of filing.

Question.heading: The validity of the priority right as such is not a ground for opposition under Article 100 EPC.

Explanation: The validity of the priority right as such is not a ground for opposition, since it is not mentioned in Article 100 EPC.

Question.heading: FR-B is state of the art under Article 54(2) EPC if the priority of EP-A is not valid.

Explanation: If the priority of EP-A is not valid, then the effective date of EP-A is the filing date of EP-A (29 February 2016). In such a case, FR-B is state of the art according to Article 54(2) EPC.

Question.heading: If the priority of EP-A is valid, then FR-B belongs to the state of the art under Article 54(3) EPC in view of its earlier filing date.

Explanation: The national application FR-B can only be prior art under Article 54(2) EPC and not under Article 54(3) EPC.

Question.heading: If the opponent raises today, 26 February 2018, an objection of lack of sufficiency of disclosure against EP-A, then this is a fresh ground for opposition.

Explanation: The objection of lack of sufficiency of disclosure was raised after the expiration of the opposition period, thus it is considered to be a fresh ground for opposition.

Question.heading: The time limit for filing a reply to the communication expires on 1 March 2018.

Explanation: The time limit for replying to the communication under Rule 71(3) EPC expires on 1 March 2018.

Question.heading: If the applicant disagrees with the amendments in EP-F, a valid option is to pay the fee for grant and publishing, to file the required translation of the claims and to file an appeal against the decision to grant after notification of the decision to grant.

Explanation: If the applicant pays the fee for grant and publishing and files the required translation of the claims, this is considered to be an approval of the text. An appeal against the decision to grant would be an appeal of a not adversely affected party.

Question.heading: If the applicant does not agree with the amendments in EP-F, a valid option is to request reasoned amendments to the communicated text.

Explanation: The applicant can disagree to the text proposed, provided he requests reasoned amendments.

Question.heading: If third party observations are filed after the decision to grant has been notified to an applicant, the observations cannot be considered by the examining division.

Explanation: The examining division may not resume the examination proceedings and consequently may not consider third party observations after the decision to grant has been handed over to the EPO's internal postal service.

Question.heading: One step that must be taken for validly entering the European phase with PCT-E today, 26 February 2018, is to pay the renewal fee.

Explanation: The renewal fee for the third year of the European patent application stemming from PCT-E are only due on 31 July 2018.
Legal basis: Rule 159(1)(g) EPC, Article 86(1) EPC, Rule 51(1) EPC

Question.heading: The time limit for entry into the European phase with PCT-E expires on 1 March 2018.

Explanation: The time limit for entry into the European phase expires on 28 February 2018.

Question.heading: One step that must be taken for validly entering the European phase with PCT-E today, 26 February 2018, is to pay the filing fee.

Explanation: The filing fee must be paid on entry into the European phase. However, the statement could be understood as referring to the concept of 'entry' versus 'early entry' into the European phase.

Question.heading: One step that must be taken for validly entering the European phase with PCT-E today, 26 February 2018, is to file the request for examination.

Explanation: The request for examination must be filed up to six months after the date on which the European search report is published in the European Patent Bulletin.

Question.heading: The catalogue is state of the art under Article 54(2) EPC for claim 1 of EP-G.

Explanation: EP-G was filed within 12 months from the filing of IT-G, and claims 1 and 3 are directed to the same invention as IT-G (frame made of metal and frame made of aluminium). The priority for claims 1 and 3 being valid, the effective date under Article 89 EPC for these two claims is the filing date of IT-G. Therefore, the catalogue is not prior art within the meaning of Article 54(2) EPC for claims 1 and 3.

Question.heading: The catalogue is state of the art under Article 54(2) EPC for claim 2 of EP-G.

Explanation: The effective date of the subject-matter of claims 2 and 4 is the date of filing of EP-G (frame made of steel and frame made of copper were not disclosed in IT-G). Thus, the catalogue is prior art under Article 54(2) EPC for these two claims.

Question.heading: The catalogue is state of the art under Article 54(2) EPC for claim 3 of EP-G.

Explanation: EP-G was filed within 12 months from the filing of IT-G, and claims 1 and 3 are directed to the same invention as IT-G (frame made of metal and frame made of aluminium). The priority for claims 1 and 3 being valid, the effective date under Article 89 EPC for these two claims is the filing date of IT-G. Therefore, the catalogue is not prior art within the meaning of Article 54(2) EPC for claims 1 and 3.

Question.heading: The catalogue is state of the art under Article 54(2) EPC for claim 4 of EP-G.

Explanation: The effective date of the subject-matter of claims 2 and 4 is the date of filing of EP-G (frame made of steel and frame made of copper were not disclosed in IT-G). Thus, the catalogue is prior art under Article 54(2) EPC for these two claims.

Question.heading: One requirement for validly entering the European phase with PCT-J is that a renewal fee must be paid.

Explanation: The renewal fee in respect of the third year for Euro-PCT-J has fallen due earlier, on 31 August 2016. For PCT-J, one of the requirements for entry into the European phase today, 6 March 2017, is the payment of the renewal fee in respect of the third year.
Legal basis: Article 86(1) EPC, Rule 51(1) EPC, Rule 159(1)(g) EPC

Question.heading: One requirement for validly entering the European phase with PCT-J is that the designation fee must be paid.

Explanation: The designation fee is due today, since the period under Rule 39 EPC has expired earlier (six months after the publication of the search report, i.e. in August 2016).

Question.heading: For entry into the European phase with PCT-J today, at least one fee for further processing must be paid.

Explanation: Today no further processing fee is (yet) due.

Question.heading: For PCT-J the EPO shall carry out a supplementary European search.

Explanation: The EPO shall carry out a supplementary European search, as the international search report takes the place of the European search report and the mention of its publication.

Question.heading: A European patent application EP1, for which a reply to a communication under Rule 71(3) EPC was to be filed at the latest on 2 March 2017, and for which the applicant did not file a reply.

Explanation: An application is not pending if it is deemed to be withdrawn due to the non-observance of a time limit, for instance failure to reply to a communication under Rule 71(3) EPC.

Question.heading: A European patent application EP2, for which the renewal fee due on 30 June 2016 has not yet been paid and for which the EPO sent a notice of loss of rights dated 2 February 2017.

Explanation: An application is not pending if it is deemed to be withdrawn due to the non-observance of a time limit, for instance failure to pay the renewal fee.

Question.heading: A European patent application EP3, which was refused by a written decision dated 28 December 2016.

Explanation: An application is pending if it was refused and if no appeal has yet been filed until the expiry of the time limit for filing the notice of appeal (7 March 2017).

Question.heading: A European patent application EP4, for which the decision to grant the European patent is dated 6 March 2017.

Explanation: The decision to grant a European patent does not take effect until the date on which the grant is mentioned in the European Patent Bulletin. Thus, EP4 is still pending today.

Question.heading: Adrienn is entitled to a reduction of the filing fee.

Explanation: Adrienn is a natural person resident in Hungary: therefore, she is entitled to a reduction of the filing fee.

Question.heading: According to the provisions of the EPC, Adrienn must file one or more claims within two months of filing of EP-A.

Explanation: One or more claims must be filed within two months of an invitation under Rule 58 EPC to correct the deficiency under Rule 57(c) EPC.

Question.heading: According to the provisions of the EPC, Adrienn must file the translation of the description within two months of filing of EP-A.

Explanation: A translation of the description must be filed within two months of filing of the European patent application.

Question.heading: According to the provisions of the EPC, Adrienn must pay the filing fee within two months of filing of EP-A.

Explanation: The filing fee must be paid within one month of filing of EP-A.

Question.heading: The statement setting out the grounds for the appeal must be filed at the latest on 5 April 2017.

Explanation: The statement setting out the grounds for the appeal must be filed at the latest on 18 April 2017 (5 December 2016 + 10 days + 4 months, extended to 18 April 2017).
Legal basis: Article 108 EPC, Rule 126(2) EPC, Rule 131(4) EPC, Rule 134(1) EPC

Question.heading: The appeal fee is reimbursed, if the applicant withdraws the appeal today, 6 March 2017.

Explanation: The appeal fee is reimbursed, if the appeal is withdrawn before the filing of the statement of grounds of appeal (and before the period for filing that statement has expired).

Question.heading: According to the provisions of the EPC, if the appeal is not allowed within four months of receipt of the statement of grounds, it shall be remitted to the Board of Appeal.

Explanation: If the appeal is not allowed within three months of receipt of the statement of grounds, it shall be remitted to the Board of Appeal.

Question.heading: The examining division will grant interlocutory revision, if the applicant can convince the examining division that claim 1 of the sole request is novel over D1.

Explanation: If interlocutory revision is to be granted, the applicant must address convincingly both grounds for refusal (novelty over D1 and inventive step over D2).

Question.heading: You are a professional representative before the EPO. Today, 6 March 2023 you have received an email from your client, Alvar, a national of Finland. He wants you to file a European patent application EP-A in his name, claiming priority from FI-A, a Finnish patent application. FI-A was jointly filed in the name of Alvar and Aino on 4 March 2022. A copy of FI-A is attached to the email. No other document or information is sent with the email.
Options: On the basis of the information given above, you can file today, 6 March 2023, a European patent application EP-A in Alvar's name at the EPO and it will be accorded 6 March 2023 as the date of filing.
You can validly file EP-A in Finnish.
On the basis of the information given above, you can be sure that EP-A can validly claim priority from FI-A.
Alvar as a natural person is not entitled to a reduction of the filing fee.

Explanation: Since you can comply on 17 March 2023 with the requirements of Rule 40(1)(a), (b) and (c) EPC, the date of filing will be 17 March 2023.
A European patent application may be filed in any language, Article 14(2) EPC.
For validly claiming the priority, Aino must have transferred the priority right to Alvar before the filing date of EP-A.
Being a national of Finland and a natural person, Alvar is entitled to a reduction of the filing fees.

Question.heading: Paula is resident in Romania and has no EPO mailbox for electronic notification. On 13 February 2023, Paula filed the European patent application EP-P as a first filing. The EPO noticed that the drawings mentioned in the description were missing. In a communication dated 22 February 2023, the EPO invited Paula to file the missing drawings.
Options: If applicants are not invited by the EPO to file missing parts of the description or missing drawings, they may validly file them within two months of the date of filing.
If Paula ignores an invitation by the EPO to file missing parts of the description or missing drawings, EP-P will be deemed to be withdrawn.
If Paula files the missing drawings on 3 May 2023, EP-P will receive 3 May 2023 as its date of filing.
Paula may validly file the missing drawings for EP-P on 6 June 2023, provided she pays the fee for further processing.

Explanation: An applicant may file missing parts of the description or drawings of their own motion within two months of the date of filing (Rule 56(2) EPC).
If ignored, references to the drawings are deemed deleted, but the application is not deemed withdrawn (Rule 56(4)(a) EPC).
If drawings are filed within 2 months of notification (4 May 2023), the application will be re-dated (Rule 56(2) EPC).
Further processing is excluded for Rule 56(2) deadlines (Rule 135(2) EPC).

Question.heading: Saïd intends to file the following patent applications in French language: (1) a European patent application EP-S (2) an international patent application PCT-SE. PCT-SE will be jointly filed in the name of Saïd and Eric. Eric lives in Paris. Saïd lives in Lebanon and is of Lebanese nationality. Lebanon is not a PCT member state.
Options: Saïd can validly file EP-S with the EPO.
If, two months after validly filing PCT-SE, Saïd moves to Paris, the EPO will, upon request, record the change of residence in relation to PCT-SE.
PCT-SE can be validly filed with the EPO as receiving Office.
PCT-SE can be validly filed with the International Bureau as receiving Office.

Explanation: There are no nationality or residence restrictions for filing a European patent application with the EPO, Articles 58 and 133(2) EPC.
Only the IB can record the residence change upon the applicant’s request, Rule 92bis.1(a)(i) PCT.
The EPO is the receiving Office competent for applicant Eric, who has his residence in a Contracting State (France).
A PCT application can be validly filed before the IB if at least one applicant is a resident or national of a PCT Contracting State.
Legal basis: Article 151 EPC, Rule 157(1) EPC, Rule 19.1(a), Rule 19.2(i) PCT

Question.heading: In 2020, company A disclosed details of a new medical device in confidence to company B. Unknown to company A, company B filed EP-B with effective filing date 6 June 2021. A final national court decision dated 10 January 2023 adjudged that company A is entitled to the grant of a European patent for the invention disclosed in EP-B.
Options: If EP-B is still pending and has not yet been granted, company A may prosecute EP-B as its own application in place of company B.
If EP-B is still pending and has not yet been granted, a request that company B must withdraw EP-B, filed by company A at the EPO, will be allowed.
If EP-B is still pending and has not yet been granted, company A may validly request that EP-B be refused.

If EP-B has been deemed to be withdrawn and is thus no longer pending, company A may still file a new European patent application EP-A in respect of the same invention, wherein EP-A shall be deemed to have been filed on 6 June 2021.

Explanation: Company A may prosecute EP-B as its own application (Art. 61(1)(a), R.16 EPC).
There are no provisions for company A to force withdrawal by B (Art. 61(1)(c) EPC).
Company A may request that EP-B be refused (Art. 61(1)(c), R.16 EPC).
Company A may file a new EP-A deemed filed on 6 June 2021 (Art. 61(1)(b), R.16 EPC, G 3/92).
Legal basis: Article 61(1)(a), Rule 16 EPC, Guidelines C-IX, 2.1(i), A-IV, 2.1(i)
No legal basis; Article 61(1)(c), Rule 16 EPC do not allow forced withdrawal
Article 61(1)(c), Rule 16 EPC, Guidelines C-IX, 2.1(iii), A-IV, 2.1(iii)
Article 61(1)(b), Rule 16 EPC, Guidelines C-IX, 2.2, A-IV, 2.1(ii), G 3/92

Question.heading: On 31 January 2022, Susanne, a German national living in Germany, filed a PCT application PCT-S in German, claiming priority from EP-S filed on 29 January 2021. PCT-S contains claim 1 from EP-S and claim 2 directed to an improved embodiment not disclosed in EP-S. PCT-S was published on 7 August 2022. She sold PCT-S to Ian, a British national, who wants to enter the regional phase before the EPO. Today is 6 March 2023.
Options: When entering the regional phase before the EPO, Ian can file an English translation of PCT-S so that the language of the proceedings of the regional phase of PCT-S will be English.
The time limit for entering the regional phase before the EPO for PCT-S claiming priority from EP-S ends on 31 July 2023.

Today, 6 March 2023, Ian can withdraw the priority claim of PCT-S in the international phase so that the time limit for entering the regional phase before the EPO for PCT-S expires on 2 September 2024.
Withdrawing the priority claim of EP-S will affect the effective date of claim 2.

Explanation: If filed and published under PCT in an EPO official language, translation into another official language upon entry into EP phase is not allowed (G 4/08).
31 months from 29 January 2021 = 29 August 2023, not 31 July.
Withdrawal of the priority claim possible until 31 July 2023, and entry time limit then becomes 2 September 2024.
Claim 2 is not entitled to priority (not disclosed in EP-S); its effective date is the filing date of PCT-S.

Question.heading: EP-P was filed on 2 December 2019 and published on 13 June 2021. First communication under Art. 94(3) EPC was received on 28 November 2021. EP-D was filed as a divisional application of EP-P on 8 December 2022. EP-P is still pending on 6 March 2023. Some EP-D claims contain subject-matter not disclosed in EP-P. Renewal fees for EP-D not yet paid.
Options: An EP divisional application cannot be validly filed after 24 months from the issuance of the first communication under Article 94(3) EPC in respect of EP-P and therefore EP-D was not validly filed as a divisional application.
The renewal fee, already fallen due, may be validly paid for EP-D on 11 April 2023 without an additional fee.
At present, EP-D is deemed to have 8 December 2022 as its date of filing.
In the present case EP-P will be regarded as prior art under Article 54(2) EPC against EP-D.

Explanation: Since 01.04.2014, a divisional can be filed as long as the parent is pending. Rule 36(1) EPC.
Renewal fees already due can be paid within 4 months from the filing of EP-D without surcharge.
If EP-D adds subject-matter not disclosed in EP-P, it cannot be converted into a separate application with 8 Dec 2022 as filing date.
EP-D has same filing date or priority as EP-P, so EP-P cannot be prior art for EP-D.

Question.heading: A company having its principal place of business in France files an international patent application at the French national patent office. The language of this international patent application is English. As a receiving Office, the French national patent office accepts international patent applications filed in French only. The International Searching Authority for this international patent application is the European Patent Office, which accepts English, French and German.
Options: The international patent application will be transmitted to the International Bureau.
The international patent application will be considered to have been received by the French national patent office on behalf of the International Bureau as receiving Office.
The search fee is collected by the International Searching Authority for its own benefit.
A translation is required by the European Patent Office for the international search.

Explanation: Because the language (English) is not accepted by the French office, the application is transmitted to the IB (Rule 19.4(b) PCT).
It is considered received by the French office on behalf of the IB (Rule 19.4(a)(ii) PCT).
The search fee is collected by the receiving Office, not the ISA (Rule 16.1(b) PCT).
No translation is required since English is accepted by the EPO as ISA (Rule 12.3(a) PCT).

Question.heading: A European patent application, EP-A, was filed in English on 2 September 2021 claiming priority from a Swedish national patent application SE-A filed on 2 September 2020. EP-A was published on 9 March 2022 and is still pending.
Options: The European examination proceedings are in progress. Third-party observations written in English are filed today and explain why a scientific journal article published in Swedish on 10 August 2020 is novelty-destroying for the claimed subject-matter of EP-A. The third-party observations are filed anonymously at the European Patent Office, together with a copy of the Swedish publication. In view of this, the third-party observations are validly filed.
Third-party observations must cite prior art documents.

The decision to grant a patent based on EP-A has already been sent to the applicant. Third-party observations are received by the EPO just before the publication of the mention of the grant. They cite a new document destroying the novelty of the allowed claims. In view of this, the examining division will consider them and resume the examination proceedings.

A patent based on EP-A has been granted. The mention of the grant was published on 1 March 2023. Third-party observations are validly filed today. In view of this, the person filing the third-party observations will be a party to the opposition proceedings if opposition proceedings start.

Explanation: Third-party observations may be filed anonymously, and can include documents in any language (Art. 115 EPC, Rule 114(1) EPC, Guidelines E-VI, 3).
Observations do not need to be based on prior art; they can relate to other patentability criteria like sufficiency, clarity, etc.
If the decision to grant has already been issued, the EPO will not consider the content of later-filed third-party observations (G 12/91, Guidelines E-VI, 3).
Filing observations does not confer party status in opposition proceedings (Art. 115 EPC, Guidelines D-I, 6).
Legal basis: Article 115 EPC, Rule 114(1) EPC, Guidelines E-VI, 3

Question.heading: When filing a European patent application with 14 claims, the applicant also submits a request for examination by filing the written request and paying the examination fee. The European Patent Bulletin mentions the publication of the European search report on 20 January 2023. The European search opinion states that claim 1 lacks novelty. The applicant receives an invitation under Rule 70(2) and Rule 70a(2) EPC dated 13 February 2023 setting a time limit of six months running from the publication of the European search report.
Options: The application shall be deemed to be withdrawn if the applicant files a reply to the invitation on 14 August 2023.
If the applicant omits in his timely reply to the European search opinion to indicate that he wishes to proceed further with the application, the application is deemed to be withdrawn.
The applicant can validly file a request for accelerated examination before timely filing of a valid reply to the invitation.
If the applicant validly replies to the invitation and files three additional claims, he must pay the claims fees for two claims within one month of filing the claims.

Explanation: The 6-month deadline from the publication of the search report (20 January 2023) ends on 20 July 2023. A reply on 14 August 2023 is too late.
A timely response to the search opinion is interpreted as confirmation to proceed, even without explicit statement (Guidelines C-II 1.1).
Accelerated examination can only be requested once the Examining Division is responsible — which is after the reply under Rule 70(2) EPC is received.
Only if the application text intended for grant contains more than 15 claims does the EPO invite to pay claim fees (Rule 71(4) EPC).

Question.heading: Applicant Andrew names Berta as sole inventor in his European patent application EP-A.
Options: The EPO informs Berta in a communication about her designation as inventor in the European patent application EP-A.
Berta can waive her right to be mentioned as inventor in the published European patent application EP-A.
If Carla was incorrectly designated as inventor in the European patent application EP-A, there is no way to request rectification of the incorrect designation.
The designation of the inventor in EP-A is required for the application to be accorded a filing date.

Explanation: There is no longer a requirement in Rule 19 EPC for the EPO to notify the inventor.
An inventor may waive their right to be mentioned (Rule 20(1) EPC).
Incorrect designations can be rectified upon request (Rule 21 EPC).
Designation of the inventor is not required for according a filing date (Rule 40 EPC).
Legal basis: Rule 19 EPC (no longer provides for this)
